one_reviews_text: ...but what is there will work to support imagining more
shows only one side of the story

There's a short "multiple choice" dialoge with a boy where you cannot really influence the direction of the conversation and where you don't get to know the boy at all. There's camera shaking that makes you VR-sick. And there's an even shorter second scene that ends appruptly while youre trying to figure out what you're supposed to do (nothing, really). The underlying topic is so important and would provide so many possibilitys for an experience that counts, but this experience is wrong on almost every level.
review_feedback:
Hi Raymii,

Thanks for your review. This is the first VR product that came out of our R&D Labs in just one month due to time constraints. Your feedback is really valuable for us to learn from the mistakes. I agree with you on the story as we wrote a full back-story for the kid and tried to integrate it into Blackbox, but we weren't sure if it would bore people or not. We decided to keep the story short, but that kept the interactions minimal.

review_title: 'We wait' by BBC was so much better
one_reviews_text: So this is a mostly cinematic VR experience that is really short. It ends very abruptly.  It only has two different interactions.  Picking up a ball and throwing it and picking up a form and reading it.  That is it.  There's hardly a story here.  There's a nice visual effect when the rubble falls above you.  Your touch controllers start shaking way too much.  There's just too many sparse details. The narrative was not well fleshed out.  I am sympathetic to the plight of children refugees across the world. But this experience did not help me understand the plight of Syrian children refugees.  It's more confusing than anything else. Way too little of substance happened way too fast.
